title: VC Daily: Europe Catching Up to U.S. in Early-Stage Deals
text:
When looking specifically at early-stage, Europe accounted for 33% of all capital invested globally this year into deals of below $5 million in size, pretty much on par with the U.S., according to the report. Europe's proportion increased from 18% in 2010 and 26% in 2015.

"The increasing share of funding in smaller rounds globally going to Europe is a leading indicator of the strength and potential of the European company pipeline," said Sarah Guemouri, a senior associate at Atomico and co-author of the report.

European tech startups raised $3.8 billion in aggregate via such smaller-sized deals, compared with about $4.1 billion by U.S. startups, through the end of September, according to the report. (The data includes the U.K. and excludes Israel.) Europe's global share of sub-$10 million rounds has been increasing over time, as well, the report said.

Another important metric that can help predict the potential of a venture market, according to the Atomico report, is the experience and size of its entrepreneur talent pool.

Atomico and Dealroom found, for example, that about 2,000 people who had been employed by the 15 largest European unicorns went on to launch their own companies. Since there are many more unicorns in Europe that are growing fast, it can be expected that they will spawn even more new companies, the report said.

And now on to the news...

Top News

Fundraising. Greycroft is raising a pair of funds, including its first-ever pool that could total $1 billion, according to people familiar with the situation, Pro's Yuliya Chernova reports. The New York- and Los Angeles-based venture investor, which backs consumer, enterprise-software, fintech and digital-health startups, is planning to raise about $1 billion for its fourth fund focused on later-stage deals, as well as about $500 million for its seventh main early-stage fund, according to people familiar with the situation.

Ian Sigalow, co-founder of the firm, declined to comment.

The rapid growth in startup valuations is leading venture firms to roll out massive funds to keep up and maintain their stakes in their high performers at the later stages.

In the U.S., 19 venture funds of $1 billion or more collected $38.7 billion in aggregate this year through the third quarter, representing about 40% of all fundraising by U.S. venture firms, according to research firm PitchBook Data Inc.

Children's Finance App Greenlight Names CFO as It Prepares for IPO

Greenlight Financial Technology Inc., the maker of an app that helps children budget, save and invest, appointed its first permanent finance chief as it prepares to go public in the next 12 to 18 months, WSJ's Mark Maurer reports. The Atlanta-based company, which generates revenue largely by selling monthly subscriptions to families that use its services, said that Brian Dong took on the chief financial officer role last month. Mr. Dong most recently served as a managing director in Goldman Sachs Group Inc.'s investment banking division. Greenlight, founded in 2014, has raised more than $550 million in venture-capital funding, including $260 million from a Series D round in April led by venture-capital firm Andreessen Horowitz.

Chinese AI Leader SenseTime Launches Scaled-Back IPO

Chinese artificial-intelligence company SenseTime Group Inc. said Monday it plans to raise up to $767 million in a Hong Kong initial public offering this month, pushing ahead with its listing plans despite a rout in Chinese technology stocks and a subsidiary's inclusion on a U.S. export blacklist, The Wall Street Journal reports. The seven-year-old company earlier aimed to raise up to $2 billion in its IPO, according to people familiar with the matter. Its scaled-back offering is backed by nine so-called cornerstone investors, including major Chinese state-owned companies and investment funds, which will purchase 60% of the shares being sold.

Industry News

Funds

Israeli seed-stage investor lool ventures held the first $60 million close of its third fund, which is targeting $100 million, and seeks to back approximately 20 companies. The Tel Aviv-based firm also recently promoted Tony Saigh to partner from vice president of value creation. Lool ventures recently participated in funding rounds for voice technology startup Eleos Health, mobile e-signature and e-document services provider Lightico and traffic management platform NoTraffic.

People

Bain Capital Ventures named Christina Melas-Kyriazi as the firm's newest partner. She will be based in the San Francisco office, and will focus on seed and Series A investments in emerging fintech and commerce companies. She previously held leadership roles at Affirm and GoFundMe. Earlier this year, Bain Capital Ventures closed two new funds worth a combined $1.3 billion and announced a renewed focus on seed and Series A deals.

ImmunOs Therapeutics AG, a Swiss company developing a new class of biologics for the treatment of cancer and autoimmune diseases, named Steve Coats to the post of chief development officer. He previously held the same position at Auregen BioTherapeutics. ImmunOs Therapeutics is backed by Pfizer Ventures, BioMed Partners and Redalpine, among others.

Escape Bio Inc., a developer of therapeutics for genetic neurodegenerative diseases, said Mark Kaufmann joined the company as chief financial officer and chief business officer. He was most recently chief financial officer and head of corporate development at Ardelyx Inc. South San Francisco, Calif.-based Escape Bio is backed by investors including Wellington Management, OrbiMed, Novo Holdings, Novartis Venture Fund and New Leaf Ventures.

New Money

Genesys, a Daly City, Calif.-based customer experience platform, scored a $580 million investment valuing the company at $21 billion. Salesforce Ventures led the round, which included participation from investors including ServiceNow Ventures, Zoom Video Communications, funds and accounts managed by BlackRock and D1 Capital Partners.

YipitData, a New York-based data analytics provider, landed as much as $475 million in Series E funding led by Carlyle Group, giving the company unicorn status. Norwest Venture Partners first backed the company in 2018.

Incode, a San Francisco-based identity verification and authentication platform, secured $220 million in Series B funding, giving the company a $1.25 billion valuation. Lead investors General Atlantic and SoftBank were joined by J.P. Morgan, Capital One Ventures, Coinbase Ventures, Silicon Valley CISO Investments, DN Capital, 3L Capital, Framework Ventures, Dila Capital and others in the round.

The Every Company, a South San Francisco, Calif.-based animal-free protein startup, closed a $175 million Series C round. McWin and Rage Capital co-led the funding, which included additional support from Temasek Holdings, Wheatsheaf Group and Prosus Ventures.

TradeDepot Inc., a business-to-business e-commerce and embedded finance platform currently serving cities in Nigeria, Ghana and South Africa, secured $110 million in Series B equity and debt. International Finance Corp. led the equity portion, which saw participation from Novastar, Sahel Capital, CDC Group, Endeavor Catalyst, Partech and MSA Capital. Arcadia Funds led the debt financing. IFC's Wale Ayeni and Novastar's Brian Odhambo will join the company's board. TradeDepot has offices in Nigeria and San Francisco.

ServiceTrade, a Durham, N.C.-based provider of software-as-a-service applications for commercial service contractors, fetched an $85 million growth investment. JMI Equity led the round, which included contributions from Frontier Growth and Bull City Venture Partners. David Greenberg and Stephen Jones, both of JMI, will join the board.

Hometap, a Boston-based startup providing a loan alternative for tapping into home equity without taking on debt, picked up a $60 million investment. Led by American Family Ventures, the round included contributions from Bain Capital, Iconiq Capital, G20 Ventures, Pillar and General Catalyst.

Nearside, a San Francisco-based free small business checking account provider, raised a $58 million Series B round. Valar Ventures led the funding, with additional participation from Kleiner Perkins, Foundation Capital, Abstract Ventures and others.

Sense, a San Francisco-based recruiting startup, nabbed a $50 million Series D investment led by SoftBank Vision Fund 2.

Stacked, a Chicago-based crypto-investing software provider, collected $35 million in Series A financing. Alameda Research and Mirana Ventures led the round, which included participation from Fidelity International Strategic Ventures, DRW Venture Capital, Alumni Ventures and Jump Capital.

Hummingbird RegTech, a San Francisco-based provider of risk and compliance technology, snagged $30 million in Series B financing. Led by Battery Ventures, the round included support from Flourish and Homebrew.

Ayla Networks Inc., a Milpitas, Calif.-based provider of internet-of-things services to consumer brand manufacturers and Internet service providers, grabbed $20 million in growth equity funding. Arrowroot Capital led the round, with Vice President Thomas Oh joining the board. Voyager Capital and SJF Ventures also invested in the round.

Tech News

Alibaba reshuffles e-commerce teams amid competition, slowing growth

Why the world's biggest traders are betting on blockchain data
